title: brexit-day-state-parties-britain-enters-final-hours-eu-membership
story: We have seen the Beast from the East, royal weddings and births, and encountered the devastating events of Grenfell Tower and the Manchester Arena terror attack.But in politics, while dates have been postponed and party leadership contested, January  is finally upon us, and with it, our exit from the European Union.But off the back of theyears of back and forth negotiations and elections, what does our countrys political spectrum look like as we leave In December last year, Britain held a rare Christmas-time general election, which saw the Conservatives take home a landslide victory.:lsquoTime is extremely, extremely shortrsquo: the view from BrusselsIn total,  seats changed hands, with the Conservatives making  gains but losing ten seats, Labour gaining one seat but losing , and the SNP gaining  seats and losing one.Between them, Conservatives and Labour won % of the UK vote - a far cry from the .% in , but a substantial increase than the .% combined vote share they won in .In Scotland, the SNP took home another country-wide victory, claiming  seats out of its  on offer.As a result, they are looking to press forward with plans to hold a second referendum on Scottish independence, with the First Minister expected to make a statement regarding next steps on Friday:How the front pages of Britains papers look on Brexit DayThe Prime Minister has already rejected Nicola Sturgeons calls for a Section  order, which would grant Holyrood the necessary powers to hold such a vote.But whatever the future holds, be sure to stick with The Herald for daily insight, opinion and analysis from some of the countrys leading writers and commentators.

title: Rosemary Goring  Edinburgh is selling its soul
story: Reassurances by Edinburgh City Council that this part of the gardens will be restored to its "annual summer glory" within  weeks are crass. To turn the area over to commercial activities from November, with an unsightly and unpassable clear-up lasting from January to May, is to commandeer the place for more than half the year. Eight weeks would be acceptable  is not.Naturally, this eyesore wont be published on any VisitScotland website. Most sightseers wont ever catch a glimpse of this inglorious aftermath. Meanwhile, between now and the middle of May, those who live and work in Edinburgh must pass by and avert their gaze, wondering how their city became a mere pawn of the entertainment industry and not an illustrious capital of which they could once be proud. As one of many disgruntled locals tweeted, this is ruination "in the name of greed".I cannot think of a city of comparable elegance, venerability and wealth ndash a Unesco World Heritage Centre to boot ndash where the first thing you see as you emerge from the train station, or arrive from the airport is a wasteland. Welcome to Scotland! Here we dont roll out the red carpet, but ndash after an agonisingly long delay ndash we do renew the turf.Theres a palpable feeling at the moment that Edinburgh is undergoing seismic change, under our noses but without public consent. News last week that planning regulations could be relaxed to allow restaurants, cafes, and a host of other non-retail outfits to move into Princes Street is a fresh cause for concern. If approved, this new dispensation could mean that one of Europes most beguiling bouleds ndash the street that sells Scotland ndash could become home to a casino, cinema, or even a sports facility.Why should this concern us  Given the tawdry quality of some of the shops currently trading, wouldnt bright cafes or restaurants be a welcome improvement  After all, the array of tartan tat, cheap-as-chips fashion and even an emporium dedicated to sugary sweets ndash the smell alone could rot your teeth ndash is hardly in keeping with the magnicence of the venue.Yet given some of the poor decisions already taken by the councils planning committee, it is hard to feel confident that this incomparably lovely avenue is in safe hands. One member of the committee says the idea is to create a "more authentic" space. Im not sure what that means, but it sounds like double-speak for attracting lucrative footfall. And while pubs wont apparently be allowed onto the street, this relaxing of regulations extends to George Street, Hanover Street, Frederick Street and Castle Street. Like it or not, the face of the New Towns commercial district is set for a facelt.With the demise of House of Fraser at the West End, now transformed into a whisky experience, and towards the East End the once-beloved Jenners department store due shortly to close , the heart of the city is struggling to keep up with bewildering change. Fortunately, nothing so awful is in the pipeline as the notorious proposal some years ago to build an elevated shopping mall in the gardens. Perhaps the most worrying aspect of a less stringent commercial climate is the signal it sends, and the trend it looks set to deepen.Wherever you go, Edinburgh is turning into a visitor attraction, a living museum and gallery. Useful shops for locals are a rarity. In their place is a proleration of chic cafes, glitzy on-trend eateries and luxurious hotels, all pandering to the tourist market. Thanks to the make-over of old premises and investment in new, the capital has a superficial shine, a high-cost stylish patina. But as Dickenss Mr and Mrs Veneering showed, putting your faith in appearances is risky. Yes, it creates jobs, though mostly of a lowly-paid, transitory kind. But at what cost  Do people make the trip to Edinburgh for its pubs and coffee shops, or to soak up the atmosphere of culture, history and daily le that, over centuries, have made its name Princes Street has undoubtedly been in need of improving its image for a long time now. Some initiatives are to be welcomed, such as the Quaich project, to renovate the run-down Ross Bandstand, and to "wild" the western part of the gardens, so they look less like a postcard from the s and rather more invitingly freeform. While that is a laudable aspiration for one side of the street, however, the other is in danger of losing whatever soul it has left.I understand that the council is in a dficult position, trying to safe-guard the future of a district caught in the retail nightmare of swtly changing, quixotic customer behaviour. That it is hoping to welcome a greater ersity of trade suggests that in one aspect at least, human habits are unchanged: eating and drinking and watching the world go by. In fact, we are consuming far more than we ever did before, willing to spend money as well as countless hours sipping lattes and beer and scoffing burgers and sushi. So much for austerity. When it comes to leisure, wallets fly open.There would be nothing wrong with broadening Princes Streets commercial scopeyou could trust those at the controls. Sadly, I have no such faith. On the evidence of recent years, the citys development is geared towards immediate gratication, mainly for migrating flocks of cash-splashing customers. Where is the long-term perspective, tailored to the true character of the city, and to the requirements and concerns of those who live in it  Why bother to ask. Such a perspective requires serious thought, knowledge and imagination, luxuries the current decision-makers dont want to afford. As they say, Rome wasnt built in a day ndash but a theme park could be.

title: no-faffing-about-demands-reroute-landslip
story: More than , tonnes of material reached the carriageway, despite catch-fences above the carriageway, in the early hours of Thursday morning following heavy rainfall.Commuters were initially directed on the huge reroute westbound and eastbound by Traffic Scotland before being directed to the Old Military Road which runs parallel to the stricken road.The Scottish Government spent millions on reopening the single-track Old Military Road in  as an alternative for drivers faced with a long detour.It was originally built in the mid-th century and used to move troops around the country.:Rest and Be Thankful closure -Motorists face -mile ersion after landslipBusinesses who rely on the important Highlands artery, believe a permanent solution to the landslip issues has to have been found by now.And Aileen Morton, the Argyll and Bute Council leader said there should be "no more preicating and faffing about" after a decade ofrequests for a permanent solution and that the Scottish Government should make a commitment to resolving the issue "right now".Iain Jurgensen, chairman of the Argyll and The Isles Tourism Co-operativesays a solution is available to reroute the road using an existing track which has not got the same slippage issues.Bear Scotland said on Thursday that staff were at the Rest And Be Thankful and would begin a clearance operation when it was safe.The A connects the Central Belt, via the A from Glasgow, to the Kintyre peninsula, all the way down to Campbeltown.The latest major landslip to hit the road came on the day of the Inverary funeral of one of the leading campaigners for solutions to the A, Donald Clark, who ran the George Hotel in the town, and sat on the road taskforce.Mr Jurgensen, who is also managing director of Portavadie, the popular holiday resort overlooking Loch Fyne, said: "That road is a leline. How many more times does it have to happen before it falls on someone who is actually travelling. Do people have to die before anything happens."That might sound melodramatic, butyou are beneath that landslip when you are driving through at night..."This piecemeal approach is just not what is required.The suggested reroute"I have had to come through Helensburgh across the ferry to get to work. We have a full house of guests arriving today."And we have Mr Clark, whose funeral many people will have been trying to get to. It is ironic that the road they would use to play their last respects, is not open today, given his views.":Rest and Be Thankful partially reopens after Storm Callum landslip chaosHe said having spoken to contractors and people who have carried out goods transportation in the area for years he has found the consistent solution was to reroute the road using a track running parallel to the the A."The land is already owned by the Forestry Commission and it does not have the same kind of slippage because the terrain is completely dferent."With the climate dfering, the amount of rainfall coming down, is this the right way forward to have [short term] mitigation. It has not caught the debris. It might have reduced the amount to get the road open quicker, but it is still not a long-term solution."We need a robust, key artery road that is open constantly."If this was Edinburgh, we would have had three dferent routes to choose from by now."And is not the voters here that are the only ones affected, it is the millions who come to do business, or to be tourists. "It affects a businesss viability when people choose to go where because they lose confidence that the road will be open during the winter. It is seriously bad PR for all Argyll busineses, trying very hard to stay afloat in dficult, challenging times."Drone footage taken earlier from the team at #GeoRope of the landslip on the #A #RestandBeThankful. Over  tonnes of debris reached the carriageway, the road remains open via the Old Military Road ersion route. More information can be found here: https:t.co SGyApoOVhl pic JUXhdrpBIBear Scotland, which said it received reports of debris on the A at am said ferry options were also available to travellers via Western and CalMac Ferries.The Rest and Be Thankful is the highest point of a scenic ten mile route running from Tarbet to the As junction with the B. The words Rest  Be Thankful are inscribed on a stone near the junction, placed there by soldiers who built the original military road in , now referred to as the Drovers road.The road closed for several days in  following a , tonne landslip, then again in  after a huge boulder threatened the safety of traffic. A controlled explosion had to be carried out on the -tonne rock.In October , the road was shut for nine days after about , tonnes of landslide debris reached catch-fences above the carriageway.Ms Morton added: ldquoThe Scottish Government needs to make a commitment right now to finding a permanent solution for the A ndash no more preicating and faffing about, no more talking about processes and procedures, no more delays."The A is a crucial part of Argyllrsquos transport network and therefore a crucial part of Scotlandrsquos transport network when you consider the scale of high value products such as whisky, timber and seafood that are produced here.ldquoThe last landslip had a hugely negative impact on local businesses, and as well as day-to-day inconvenience for local residents it caused problems with essential services such as access to medical treatment."The council and the people of Argyll and Bute have been asking for a permanent solution for a decade. Enough is enough ndash we need an announcement today that work is starting on finding a permanent solution.

title: time-extremely-extremely-short-view-brussels
story: DEEP within the glassy, bureaucraticedices of central Brussels, through the security gates and along bright, al corridors, weary officials are gearing up for another busy year.ldquoI think wersquore not allowed to talk about Brexit anymore, one joked. ldquoItrsquos now lsquothe future relationship with the United Kingdomrsquo.We may be leaving the EU tonight, but the upheaval of the last few years is far from over. In many ways, the end is barely even in sight.Months of negotiations lie ahead as Boris Johnson and European leaders thrash out a future relationship over issues such as trade and security.Behind the scenes, officials in Brussels are clear about the challenges looming on the horizon.And while the Prime Minister insists the transition period will end on December  this year, there is a suspicion several issues will run over into .The European Commission will put forward its draft mandate for the future negotiations in the coming days, which will then need to be approved by the  remaining member states.ldquoWe probably wonrsquot start formal negotiations until the end of February, beginning of March, said one senior source, setting out the tight timescale.ldquoThen we have until ndash Irsquom being very approximatehere ndash September, October, because you need to leave time for whatever agreement we reach to be ratied.ldquoAnd in between that time, you have the deadline of July  for a very important decision to be made ndash and that is the decision on whether or not we extend the transition period.They added: ldquoTime is extremely, extremely short, but we can only do what we can during that time.ldquoIt may require us prioritising certain things, and it may require certain elements to be pushed into the future as well. We will just have to wait and see.The official said there are existing contingency measures in some areas, or international fallback options.ldquoI think in terms of priority, wersquore going to be looking at security and defence cooperation, the economic relationship, fisheries, all that sort of stuff, they added.ldquoBut it may be the case that certain things arenrsquot done by the end of the year, and they will just have to continue.ldquoAndthose negotiations continue in , thatrsquos possible but yoursquore going to be in a very dferent situation, because the UK will be outside the single market and customs union.ldquoWersquoll have to be negotiating, but in a much more stressful environment, because there will be no status quo, as it were ndash the UK will be outside.Security will be a big issue going forward.The UK played a key role in setting up a new super-database of seven dferent systemsintended to protect borders and stop terrorists or organised crime gangs slipping through the net.But after Brexit, it risks being denied access to this.Fears have also been raised over the loss of access to European Arrest Warrantsand Europol, the EUrsquos law enforcement agency.One Brussels official described Europol asldquoa bit of a Scottish colony, given the crucial role Scots have played in its operations.Another said: ldquoThe UK is a serious security player, therefore there must be an interest from the EU side to have a relationship.ldquoBut there hasnrsquot ever been anything like this, so there are no obvious third country precedents.ldquoEven the precedent with the US, which is probably a closer security relationship than with any other third country is not quite analogous.Everyone agrees itrsquos in the interests of both sides to cooperate.But officials say itrsquos not that simple.ldquoJust because something is logical, which it is, and even wanted, which I suspect it is, does not mean itrsquos easy, and it isnrsquot easy because this is a legal entity, one said.ldquoThe EU is a legal entity more than itrsquos a political club.ldquoAnd therefore there are a whole set of rights and responsibilities in that, andyou decide that you are leaving certain things ndash like the jurisdiction of the court ndash then that creates a lot of things that you have to then find a workaround [for].Fishing is another crucial area, and there has been speculation the UK will trade access to its waters infor a deal on financial services.Downing Street dismissed this when it was recently suggested by Irish TaoiseachLeo Varadkar.But as one Brussels trade official put it, other EU countries land about euro million-worth of fish in UK waters.There are half a dozen or so EU member states, including France, with a powerful interest in maintaining access. Its a useful illustration of where an agreement could be struck.And what of Scotland  Nicola Sturgeon is due to set out her next steps on independence today, following Boris Johnsonrsquos rejection of her request for the power to hold a second referendum.There is clearly goodwill in Brussels towards Scotland.But officials are understandably loath to say anything concrete on the possibility of an independent Scotland rejoining the EU.ldquoYou might want to ask somebody  that question, replied one. ldquoI am a mere ary. Itrsquos a question that could become increasingly pressing.

title: energy-boss-lays-green-vision
story: Deirdre Michie, chief executive of OGUK, told an an audience of politicians, policymakers and campaign groups in Edinburgh that new and emerging green technologies would be key to meeting the Scottish Government target.Ms Michie said: ldquoWe now need to move the debate on from talking about the need to act, to demonstrating what we are doing to act.ldquoWe have a plan ndash Roadmap  ndash which offers a blueprint for net zero.ldquoIt is one of the first industrial responses to the UK and Scottish governments net zero commitments.ldquoIt aims to enable a safe, sustainable and competitive oil and gas industry supporting the UKrsquos energy needs and its transition to a net zero future.The Scottish Government unveiled its emissions reduction target in September last year, with a pledge that Scotland would stop contributing greenhouse gas pollution by  ndash five years earlier than the UK deadline.The target relates to ldquonet zero carbon emissions, meaning that human-caused greenhouse gases such as those released by fossil-fuel vehicles and factories should be reduced to as close to zero as possible, with any remaining emissions offset by tree-planting or technologies such as carbon capture.Ms Michie said the sector currently contributes  per cent of the UKrsquos greenhouse gas emissions.Achieving net-zero target would mean a reduction from  million tonnes per year to . million tonnes by .This ldquowill require signicant investment, new technology and close working with the renewables sector in Scotland and across the UK said Ms Michie, adding that a combination of hydrogen alongside advances in carbon capture and storage would be key.Ms Michie said: ldquoReports by Swansea and Keel Universities found up to % of the UKrsquos gas supply can be replaced with hydrogen without needing to mody peoplersquos appliances.ldquoWith currently % of the UKrsquos heating demand in buildings being met by natural gas, it shows the scale of the opportunity, and the analysis from the International Energy Agency showing that the cost of producing hydrogen from renewable electricity could fall % by  as a result of declining costs of renewables and the scaling up of hydrogen production helps us to begin to see what a truly transitional and transformational approach could look like.ldquoBlue hydrogen derived from gas will need to compete alongside green hydrogen made from renewables ndash but both will be needed.She added that developing a hydrogen economy could ldquobring far-reaching benefits to Scotland.ldquoFor example, in Orkney, where a consortium led by the [Oil  Gas Technology Centre] alongside universities and oil companies are looking to create a test centre at Flotta oil terminal for trialling these dferent types of technologies for use on offshore s.The oil and gas sector currently employs one in every  working people in Scotland.Concluding, Ms Michie said: ldquoThe premature shutdown of this industry in the UK would do nothing to impact consumption.ldquoThose needs would instead be met from increasing the amount of oil and gas imported from across the world,ldquoBut it would also mean we realise none of the benefits this indigenous industry brings in jobs, taxation and security of supply.

title: new-dawn-uk-countrys-divisions-remain
story: The Prime Minister is set to broadcast his televised address to the country just one hour before it leaves the European Union at pm after a relationship spanning  years.Earlier, he will chair a special Brexit Cabinet in Sunderland, a symbolic location for Brexit supporters as it was, three and a half years ago, the first city to declare support for leaving the EU.This evening, a clock will be projected onto the faccedilade of No  to count down to Brexit. Buildings across Whitehall will be illuminated in the Union colours of red, white and blue, while Union flags will be flown at Parliament Square and down the Mall.However, the mood north of the Border will be more sombre, with a series of candle-lit vigils planned to mourn the departure.The Leave a Light On gatherings are taking place in Aberdeen, Dundee, Glasgow and Stirling, among other locations, as participants express their sadness and send a message to the EU not to forget Scotland.Scots voted by % to % to Remain in the EU, while the overall UK result in the  referendum backed Leave by % to %.In his televised address, Mr Johnson will say: ldquoOur job as the Government, my job, is to bring this country together and take us forward. And the most important thing to say tonight is that this is not an end but a beginning.ldquoThis is the moment when the dawn breaks and the curtain goes up on a new act. It is a moment of real national renewal and change, he will declare.ldquoThis is the dawn of a new era in which we no longer accept that your le chances, your familyrsquos le chances, should depend on which part of the country you grow up in. This is the moment when we begin to unite and level up., the PM will add.As Brexit happens, he will host a reception in No  for Downing Street staff.While the Brexiteers failed in their campaign to get Big Ben to bong in Brexit, they have organised a mass celebration in Parliament Square. Nigel Farage, the Brexit Party leader, is expected to be there.Alister Jack said Britainrsquos departure from the EU tonight was finally honouring the result of the  referendum.The Scottish Secretary said: ldquoI know that Scotland, and the rest of the UK, will flourish outside of the EU our coastal communities will leave the hated Common Fisheries Policy, our farmers will benefit from a system of funding that works for them and we will strike lucrative trade deals around the globe, opening up new markets for Scotlandrsquos world-class businesses.ldquoWe will take back control of our borders, our laws and our money, allowing us to invest in the ambitious infrastructure projects the UK needs.He added: ldquoWe will build a stronger economy, creating opportunity and prosperity for everyone. We will move forward together, as one United Kingdom, to a bright future.ldquoItrsquos time for Nicola Sturgeon to drop her constant demands for independence and instead work with us to ensure a prosperous future for Scotland.: lsquoTime is extremely, extremely shortrsquo: the view from BrusselsJeremy Corbyn said that Britain from today stood at a crossroads.ldquoAs we leave the EU, we have an opportunity to shape our future role within the international community for decades to come. Britainrsquos place in the world will change. The question is what direction we now take.ldquoWe can work with other countries to develop trade, improve rights and protections, invest in our communities, tackle the threat of climate catastrophe, fight human rights abuses and promote peace. We can build a truly internationalist, erse and outward-looking Britain.ldquoOr we can turn inwards, and trade our principles, rights and standards to secure hastily arranged, one-sided, race-to-the-bottom trade deals with Donald Trump and others.Labour, he insisted, would ldquoalways want to ensure a close, strong and co-operative relationship with the European Union.The Labour leader added: ldquoWhatever side we took in the Brexit debate, we now need to bring the country together to shape our common future, work to rebuild and strengthen our communities, and eliminate poverty and injustice in our society.Yesterday afternoon, Mr Johnson visited the Department for Exiting the EU to thank staff for their ldquohard work.He said: ldquoWe are leaving the EU and will become an independent country again ready to determine our own future. Some of you would have joined at the beginning of the journey and others more recently, but without your combined efforts we would not be where we are today.The department ceases to exist at pm. Staff have all been promised jobs where in Government they want one. Stephen Barclay, the Brexit Secretary, will also be out ofa job.Diplomatic engagement around the trade negotiations will be the responsibility of the Foreign Office, with the implementation of the Withdrawal Agreement and readiness for the transition period in  overseen by the Cabinet Office.From tomorrowSaturday, the Governmentrsquos ldquoTask Force Europe, a team of  officials leading the trade negotiations, will be headed by David Frost, the Governmentrsquos chief adviser on Europe, who will report directly to the PM.UKRep or UKMis will become the official UK mission in Brussels, while Sir Tim Barrow, Britainrsquos Permanent Representation in Brussels, will become its ambassador to the EU.Next week, Mr Johnson is due to give a keynote speech in London looking ahead to the hoped-for trade deal between the UK and the EU.He has insisted there will be no formal policy of alignment and that post-Brexit Britain would become a rule maker not a rule taker.However, Simon Coveney, the Irish Minister for Foreign Affairs, warned that without a ldquolevel playing field, there would be no EU trade deal with Britain post-Brexit.The Tanaiste said any ersion from Britain on workersrsquo rights or competition rules would scupper negotiations for a future trading relationship with the EU.ldquoThere wonrsquot be a trade dealthere isnrsquot a level playing field, one that is robust and credible, declared Mr Coveney.: Brexit: Auf wiedersehen, adieu, goodbye - its been a blastldquoStandards will have to be maintained in regards to environmental standards, or workersrsquo rights and so on.ldquoThat is only half of the challenge, the other half is around fair competition. If the UK is trying to derive a competitive advantage for its own companies in order to trade into the EU -thatrsquos the objective there will be no trade deal, he added.Ian Blackford for the SNP claimed it was ldquofancul to believe Mr Johnson would complete a comprehensive trade arrangement with the EU by December and suggested there ldquocould still be an extension to the transition.The partyrsquos Westminster leader said there was ldquoreal sadness at the UK leaving the EU, noting how much Scotland had benefited from membership ndash economically, socially and culturally. He recalled that a meeting in London with EU ambassadors earlier this week had been ldquoquite emotional.He added: ldquoWe are demonstrating that message to keep a light on for us, that we fully intend to see Scotland become an independent country and to be a member of the EU. We see that very much as our destiny.Elsewhere at Westminster, Tory Brexiteer backbencher Peter Bone suggested the Friday closest to the EU referendum date should be made a bank holiday, saying he planned to introduce a Bill calling for ldquoUnited Kingdom Day on the Friday closest to June  every year.Meanwhile, the PMrsquos spokesman, answered one journalistic query about what the Government would be doing on Brexit come Saturday by saying: ldquoBrexit will be done on Saturday. We wonrsquot be speaking about it anymore.

title: unspun-political-diary
story: WEIRD news arrives of Scottish Labourrsquos election finances. We hear the party was so deluded, it actually outspent the SNP in Edinburgh East and Edinburgh North  Leith. Nats Tommy Sheppard and Deidre Brock duly gained votes, Labour went backwards. The next accounts will be a hoot. Meanwhile, the messiest candidate- printed at the wrong angle, no invoices etc - belonged to Nat Sarah Masson in Edinburgh West. Perhaps her agent should have been more diligent. He was, after all, only city council leader Adam McVey.Double barrelSO farewell then, Fergus Mutch. The SNPrsquos affable spindoctor is leaving Holyrood next week - Fergexit, as he calls it - and is planning a drinks bash. Itrsquos a popular idea. Tory Scottish Secretary Alister Jack is having drinks for the media at exactly the same time, leaving hacks with a dilemma about where to sink a pint. ldquoItrsquos typical of the political class, grumbles one. ldquoFor years they canrsquot organise a p***-up in a brewery, then two come along at once.Spin cycleTALKING of spindoctors, LibDem Max Sefton couldnrsquot resist a pop at a Labour counterpart in the Holyrood bar on Thursday. As everyone talked about Richard Leonardrsquos legendary PFI misfire at FMQs, Max suggested the Scottish Labour leader may have been getting some poisoned advice. ldquoSo did Anas Sarwar or Jackie Baillie write that question  he asked. Mr Leonardrsquos heart-broken supporter was genuinely lost for words.Lunar raverALSO in the bar last week was Lanarkshire SNP MSP Richard Lyle, universally known as Salty Dick after once claiming a bag of chips on expenses. As well as a bon viveur, it seems Mr Lyle is also a conspiracy buff. After repeatedly asking BBC political guru Brian Taylor who really killed JFK, Salty moved onto the moon landings, noting not everyone believed in them. At which Brian swtly shut the mad conversation down. Then again, why visit the moon when you have Lanarkshire Naw bagsALLAN Dorans, new Nat MP for Ayr, tried appealing to the better side of human nature in his maiden speech this week. We agreed we would work together collaboratively for the benefit of our constituents and not along political lines - perhaps a model that could be followed by others. At which an SNP colleague scoffed and let out a loud ldquoNaw! Wersquore looking at you, Chris Stephens.Island leMUCH muttering in the Yes ranks ahead of Nicola Sturgeonrsquos lsquonext stepsrsquo speech. One of those plugging a Plan B on Indyref, Inverclyde councillor Chris McEleny, put out a press release saying he hoped the FM would be ldquoradical. In doing so, he gave a nod to his fellow Plan B-er, Angus MacNeil, describing him as the MP for the ldquoWestern Aisles.
